div.p: Term in printing denoting an engraved block (copper, zinc) or plate, and by inference a proof pulled from such a block or plate.

In Schenker's work, Klischees were used for musical examples, small Urlinie graphs, and diagrams that appear in the course of text. The type for the surrounding text was set up first in galleys, proofs of which Schenker corrected, while simultaneously the examples were engraved on blocks, proof-pulls from which Schenker corrected. Then the galleys were subdivided into pages, at which stage the engraved blocks were embedded within the type.

In the many places in correspondence where Schenker and Universal Edition speak of Klischees, and where in his diary Schenker speaks of receiving and correcting them, "Klischee" must be an abbreviation for "Klischeeabzug," a proof-pull from an engraved block, or possibly "Klischeekorrektur," a proof from an engraved block, since Schenker would have been unable to do anything with the block itself, which was printed in reverse.

The sole occasion on which the term denoted the blocks themselves arises in a letter from Schenker's attorney listing items delivered to him by UE, which included "196 Klischees for Tonwille Hefte 1–10 [and] 13 sheets of Klischee proof-pulls" (OC 52/538, December 18, 1925).
